author: Amber Thomas

intro.value: When you spend a lot of time in the same place, you start to notice little things you’d overlooked in the past.

#quarantine2020 has personally made me hyper-aware of the words that Netflix uses to tag its programs. Check out the 43 titles and tags that Netflix displayed on my TV’s screensaver and see if you notice what I did.

postTv.value: Did you see it? The high-level categories like drama and comedy are going the way of the video stores that depended on them for categorization. Only to be replaced with words like witty and irreverent.

The use of irreverent in particular has become something that I can’t. Stop. Noticing. And it’s not hard to see why. It was the most popular descriptive word shown to me across a wide variety of programs.

Now, I know what you’re going to say. Netflix’s algorithms are probably advertising things that it thinks I would like based on my own viewing preferences. It’s definitely possible that I am causing my own irreverent doom.
So, I created a brand new profile with no viewing preferences and recorded the tags for the first 141 shows on the Netflix homepage. Irreverent is still the second most common.

commonTitle: Most Common Words Used to Describe Titles on Netflix
commonSub: Out of 141 titles shown to brand new profiles in April 2020

preTogether.value: After looking at the data, I’m feeling slightly vindicated. Netflix really is using the word irreverent a ton. But I’m also feeling even more annoyed, because out of all of the most common words, irreverent is the one that feels the least intuitive for users. In fact, it’s the only one that’s an actual SAT word.

Maybe you already know what it means. But if you don’t, maybe you’ll employ one of those SAT test-taking strategies to help you out. Try using the other 2 descriptive words alongside it as context clues to help you figure out what it means so you can decide whether you want to watch that show or let it pass on by.
Good luck. irreverent was also paired with the second highest number of unique descriptive words. Here’s what it was paired with:

preConclusion: Don’t worry about looking it up. Here’s the definition of irreverent:
def: Irreverent: showing a lack of respect for people or things that are generally taken seriously

conclusion.value: So these are titles that poke fun at things that may come across as disrespectful or offensive. Titles like The Hangover (absurd, raunchy), The Office (witty, sitcom), and Step Brothers (slapstick, raunchy) may seem to fit the bill well and are considered irreverent by Netflix. Using irreverent as a tag for these titles (assuming that you know what it means) will at least give you an accurate heads up about what you’re about to watch.

But other titles, like Orange is the New Black, a “dramedy” centered around the experiences of people residing in a women’s prison is described as deadpan, witty, and irreverent. To describe this series in the same way as Derry Girls does new viewers that may not be expecting the heavy drama element of the show a disservice.

Even still, other titles like Grace and Frankie, a show devoted to the post-divorce life of two women who (among many other things) develop a line of vibrators for the elderly, are apparently not irreverent. The show is described as heartfelt, witty, and quirky. I’m certainly not here to advocate that we should be using this word to describe more titles, but it seems like its use is inconsistent at best and misleading to viewers at worst.

I know that with everything going on in the world right now, the words Netflix uses to describe their titles probably feels like the least important thing. I’m not even about to argue with you about that. But as stay-at-home orders continue across the world, Netflix usage is booming. The global platform saw an astounding 15.7 million new subscribers in the past quarter, double what they had been anticipating. Back in March, they even cut streaming quality in Europe to help offset the increased data consumption by home-bound streamers.

As all of these new and old users log in and look for something new to watch, they rely on the information Netflix provides to help them choose their next piece of entertainment. Back in the day when the platform opted for one-two sentence descriptions, users had thoughts. The descriptions tended to be technically accurate, but not exactly useful. According to an investigation from The Outline in 2017, this can be partially attributed to the fact that the synopsis writers were not paid “well enough...to actually watch the movies”. That was a few years and a different synopsis system ago, so I’m hopeful that things have changed at Netflix since then.

But still, it makes me wonder who is selecting these words and why irreverent is used so profusely. Are we assuming this word (which is technically a real genre of comedy) is well-understood by viewers? And I if this many shows are poking fun at “things generally taken seriously”, are those things actually taken seriously anymore? If this many things are irreverent, is anything?
